stories.title: Peloton: From Pandemic Winner to HBO Punchline

stories.text:
Hello and Happy New Year HN! Hope all the bests in 2022. So I've been working on a minimal calendar app , named Clendar (Calendar without an 'a'). I know, it's not a good SEO name, but I will go with it :)

I've been building Clendar on my spare time. At first, it's just a side weekend project so that I can learn new Apple technologies, but, the app came to the point of usability that I think I should publish on the App Store anyway for the world to know and use it. Besides, I have been trying to design the app for minimal and usability in mind. Also, the app is fully open-source, as a way for me to give back to the app developers community.

+ App Store: https://apps.apple.com/app/clendar-a-calendar-app/id1548102041

+ Landing page: https://clendar.info

I'm happy to answer any questions, thanks!
stories.title: Show HN: Clendar, a Minimal Calendar App
George Orwell's Critique of Rudyard Kipling

stories.text: I don’t give a damn about Christmas, family does so I partake for the sake of them. But NYE celebrations is my thing. So happy new year to all and I hope 2022 brings more joy and prosperousness than 2021.
stories.title: Happy New Year HN

stories.text:
(I've clearly spent too much time with Feynman and quantum but...)

Quantum computing is statistical in nature. Experiments need to be performed multiple times to get reliable results.

Which got me to thinking... Quantum effects occur everywhere at room temperature. One example is the thermal noise in a resistor.

It ought to be possible to impose forces, such a magnetic fields, on the resistor to "shape" the thermal noise in various ways. Using this shaping effects it ought to be possible to impose some logic "on the noise". From there, it seems reasonable that statistical measurements could yield "computed results".

The useful point is that it ends up using quantum effects at room temperature, albeit somewhat slower than in a supercooled quantum computer. It seems reasonable that there must be a "speed vs temperature" curve for this "in the noise" computing.

One interesting experiment would be to create a Toffoli gate in a resistor using N vs S magnetic fields as the control elements. Since this would be symmetric it would also be reversible.

The end result is a "room temperature" quantum computer.
stories.title: Computing “In the Noise” Room at the Bottom
I make a fortune buying up abandoned shipping containers
